item.title: Workers Take to Streets to Calm Tense Ukrainian City
item.description: Pro-Russian militants melted away as steelworkers and miners, armed only with protective clothing and hard hats, began patrols.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mill workshop at a plant in Mariupol, Ukraine, on Thursday.

item.title: The Lede: Images of Turkish Official Kicking Protester Fuel Anger Online
item.description: The behavior of senior officials in Turkey remained under the social media microscope on Thursday, as an aide to the prime minister acknowledged that he did kick a protester the day before.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: Yusuf Yerkel, an aide to Turkey's prime minister, was photographed kicking a man during protests on Wednesday in the city of Soma.

item.title: The Lede: Turkish Prime Minister Jeered After Mine Disaster
item.description: Following a disaster in a coal mine, anger at the authorities boiled over during a visit by Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan, who was booed and called a “killer” by protesters.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: The Trade-Offs of Relocating North to Canada
item.description: The relatively few Americans who move to Canada often find that they enjoy the country’s more liberal policies and free health care, though there are adjustments to make.
item.dc:creator: By CAITLIN KELLY
item.media:credit: Daniel St. Louis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. David Bannon, a general surgeon, outside his home on Prince Edward Island. “I’m happier here than I’ve ever been,” he says.

item.title: Burials, Rage and Political Fallout in Turkey Mine Disaster
item.description: The explosion at the mine in western Turkey has galvanized discontent, and labor unions have called for a one-day strike to demand better safety standards.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM, SEBNEM ARSU and ALAN COWELL
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: Relatives of miners grieved during a funeral on Thursday in Soma, Turkey.

item.title: Egyptian Court Tells Journalists to Pay for Video Said to Show Their Guilt
item.description: The $170,000 charged for access to the evidence is the latest in a string of irregularities in the case against three men accused of fomenting unrest by broadcasting false images of civil strife.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: From left, Mohamed Fadel Fahmy, Peter Greste and Baher Mohamed in a defendent's cage on Thursday.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: May 15
item.description: Workers preparing sweets anticipating a victory for the Bharatiya Janata Party in India’s parliamentary elections.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Workers in New Delhi preparing sweets in anticipation of a victory for the Bharatiya Janata Party in the parliamentary elections. The counting of votes will take place on Friday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Activists Praise Hong Kong’s Destruction of Confiscated Ivory
item.description: Hong Kong is set to begin destroying nearly 30 tons of confiscated ivory, in a move that activists say will send a powerful message about the government’s resolve to end a trade that has contributed to widespread poaching of elephants.
item.category: Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Ivory tusks that were seized by customs officials in Hong Kong in January. Trafficking of ivory is banned under the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species.

item.title: Anti-Foreigner Violence Turns Deadly and Spreads in Vietnam
item.description: Rioting and looting at factories moved to a northern stretch of central Vietnam, with at least one person killed and scores more injured at one plant.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY, CHAU DOAN and GERRY MULLANY
item.media:description: Firefighters rested on Wednesday near a Chinese-owned shoe factory that was set afire in the Binh Duong Province of Vietnam.

item.title: India Ink: At A Memorial, Hundreds Pay Tribute To A Gujarat Human Rights Champion
item.description: The author remembers Mukul Sinha, a renowned human rights lawyer, who died on Monday.
item.dc:creator: By ZAHIR JANMOHAMED

item.title: Car Bomb Kills 17 at Syrian Border Crossing
item.description: The bombing appeared to be the latest instance of civilians bearing the brunt of clashes between Islamist groups in insurgent-held territory.
item.category: Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD

item.title: India Ink: In This Election Season, 56 Million Tweets and Counting
item.description: Twitter released data and graphics today about the social media conversation surrounding the Indian parliamentary elections.
item.dc:creator: By VISHNU VARMA
item.media:description: A screenshot of a graph that shows tweets from India per day in 2014 mentioning each party.

item.title: Letter From Europe: E.U. United on Values, but Not National Interests
item.description: The Ukraine crisis has revealed the European project to be an uneasy coalition of national agendas that cannot focus far beyond narrow interests.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Conchita Wurst, who won the Eurovision Song Contest last weekend. The gulf between Moscow and Europe is as much about competing visions of social values and the limits of tolerance as it is about territorial demarcation.

item.title: DealBook: A Shake-Up at Citigroup
item.description: The bank said it would fire 11 employees, including four top executives, in its effort to move past a costly fraud at its Mexican business.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL CORKERY and ELISABETH MALKIN
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: An branch of Citigroup's Banamex unit in Mexico City.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: 3 Officials Were Killed in Xinjiang During Chinese President’s Visit, Report Says
item.description: The three government officials, all from China’s dominant Han ethnic group, were slashed and stabbed to death on April 27, the day that President Xi Jinping arrived for a four-day tour of the troubled region.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:description: Uighur children playing on Thursday near a cage that protects heavily armed paramilitary police officers in Urumqi, the regional capital of Xinjiang.

item.title: Hopes of a Generation Ride on Indian Vote
item.description: Despite a period of rising incomes, a tide of economic discontent has helped make the challenger Narendra Modi the front-runner for prime minister.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY | Photographs by DANIEL BEREHULAK

item.title: France’s Sale of 2 Ships to Russians Is Ill-Advised, U.S. Warns
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry said in a meeting with the French foreign minister that the delivery of the vessels would not help the political situation in eastern Europe.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: The Vladivostok warship, one of two ships ordered by the Russian Army, in France last week.

item.title: Euro Zone Economy Grows More Slowly Than Expected
item.description: Gross domestic product in the 18 nations rose 0.2 percent in the first quarter of this year, as Germany helped make up for France and Italy.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY

item.title: Malfunction Causes New Setback in Search for Missing Jet
item.description: The communications system for an American deep-sea submersible used in the search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 broke down on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Great Russia’s Grand Choice
item.description: Who cares about economic deterioration, poor public services or corruption when imperialist fervor rages?
item.dc:creator: By MAXIM TRUDOLYUBOV

item.title: Captain and 3 Officers Charged With Murder in Korean Ferry Sinking
item.description: Prosecutors said the crew members failed to exercise their duty to provide aid to passengers on the doomed vessel.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Don’t Call Me Dude, Boss or Bro. It’s Comrade to You.
item.description: A series of regulations issued by party and government organizations points to an effort to step up manners among officials, and between officials and the public.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Be careful what you call them. Delegates to the National People's Congress at the Great Hall of the People in March 2013.

item.title: Results Force Runoff in Afghan Presidential Election
item.description: The front-runner, Abdullah Abdullah, won 45 percent of the votes, but it was not enough to avoid a runoff, forcing an election on June 14.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: India Ink: A Grass-Roots Drive for Clean Elections in Karnataka
item.description: An anticorruption campaign, Me and My Vote Are Not For Sale, has taken hold at the village level.
item.dc:creator: By ANKITA RAO
item.media:description: Shamala Jinnamanavar, second from left, a panchayat member in the village of B. Godihal, with local women at her home in April.

item.title: India Ink: India Election Digest: May 15
item.description: A roundup of election-related news in India for Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By NIDA NAJAR
